title: Supply shocks and the Phillips curve

content.description: Use the graph below of the long-run Phillips curve <math alttext="open parenthesis, L R P C, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>LRPC</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and short-run Phillips curve <math alttext="open parenthesis, S R P C, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>SRPC</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to answer the question.
content.question: Assume members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (<math alttext="O P E C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OPEC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) agree to a coordinated increase in oil production. If the economy is at equilibrium at point B, what effect will this have on the Phillips curve model in the long run?

choices.label: The <math alttext="S R P C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SRPC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will shift to the left.
The <math alttext="S R P C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SRPC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will shift to the right.
The <math alttext="L R P C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>LRPC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will shift to the right.
There will be a movement from point B to point C.
There will be a movement from point B to point A.

content.answer: The <math alttext="S R P C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SRPC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will shift to the left.
